value.0: Greetings of the Even-Handed to you. Welcome to the House of Tyr. I am Reverend Judge Oleff Uskar, in service of the Maimed God.
Tyr guide to you justice.
I am bound by Tyr to serve as long as the cause is just, but mind your tone. Disrespect is not tolerated in this place.
This Tyrran home welcomes your well-mannered address. Ask what you will, and I shall respond as I am able.
There are many aspects to the worship of Tyr. He is the Blind Overlord, the Even-Handed. He is the guardian and governor of justice.
The clergy are charged to reveal the truth, punish the guilty, right the wrong, and to always be true and just in their actions.
We serve as judges, juries and, should the situation require it, executioners. Justice through benevolent force and armed vigilance.
The law is unyielding, but true justice is also merciful when circumstances dictate. That can be hard to remember in times of crisis.
We administer to the plague sufferers. Previously we were working on artifact recovery, which may be even more important now.
In the weeks before the plague, we uncovered the tomb of Miaslaznia Fairblade. She traveled widely with Halueth Never, founder of Neverwinter!
This was a great discovery, and gave clues to the whereabouts of the founder's resting place. That would have been a great discovery indeed.
Contrary to your ignorant opinion, there are very valid reasons to pursue these tombs, especially now that the plague has ravaged the city.
Yes, it did. It is very unfortunate, because pursuing these tombs becomes all the more important with the city in crisis, as it is.
People are scared, and the lack of progress on a cure has diminished their hopes. A find like this would buoy their spirits.
There is also a chance that powerful artifacts could be found alongside Halueth Never's remains, though I would not rest my hopes upon it.
He was the founder of Neverwinter. Actually, not much is known about him, really. He's become a bit of a legendary figure.
Knowing the details of his life could be very beneficial to the city. The people need to know they have a history of defeating adversity.
Well, please rememeber that you are free to change your mind. Tyr be with you.
I welcome your aid in this matter. You couldn't have arrived at a more fortuitous time. There are a few other such tombs in this city.
The plague has claimed most of our kind that were searching for the tombs and artifacts. They have only left behind vague clues to locations in the city.
According to one of the researchers, there may be a tomb somewhere in the Docks district, likely in the sewers or aqueducts. Be careful in there.
There's also most likely a tomb in the Great Graveyard, though none have dared enter since the undead menace have started attacking.
Also, the first tomb that we have discovered seems to have been previously ransacked. There was evidence of some sort of relic, but it is missing.
That is all the information I have to offer, I am afraid. I wish you luck in your search.
Yes, there is indeed one last one. After you have gathered the last few artifacts, we have finished deciphering the Chronicles of Never and found a clue about a final tomb.
In fact, it would appear to be the resting place Halueth Never himself. We believe the tomb is hidden somewhere in Blacklake, likely by someone who is a descendant of his.
Good luck, my friend. I am certain you will find it.
What?! He looted our fallen even as they gasped their last from the plague? I cannot imagine a more despicable act! Such disregard!
This item is not really an artifact, but I consider it valuable nonetheless. You are truly a friend of Tyr, risking yourself as you have. Take this gold as reward. It is the least we can do.
We have not seen the like of these in many many years. It brings new light to the wisdom of Halueth Never and his companions.
As I said, you are to be rewarded. Here, take this gold. It's not much, but there is more to come.
His very armor! And the location of his tomb! Who would have thought it was just beneath the surface, amidst so many others?
It speaks of his desire to be known as just another Neverwintan. Despite his greatness, he never forgot his home.

For your part in recovering this, your efforts are truly appreciated by not only me, but the city of Neverwinter. Please, take this gold and this magic ring. May it protect you well in your adventures, <FirstName>.
An excellent find! Neverwinter will benefit from learning about its auspicious origins. Perhaps we can find historical precedent for the plague as well.
As I said, you are to be rewarded. Here, take this gold. It's not much, but there is more to come.
Greetings to you again, <FirstName>. It is good to see you return to this house of Tyr.
Farewell for now.
I'm <FirstName>. Enough chatter. I have questions for you.
My name is <FirstName>. I have some questions for you.
Hello Oleff. I am <FullName>. Will you answer some questions?
What are the tenets of the Tyrran faith?
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> That might sound harsh to some people.
What is your position here?
A waste of time, even before the plague hit.
Your efforts were likely wasted when the plague hit.
The plague undoubtedly complicated things.
What do you know about Halueth Never?
I have no interest in this.
I will help you find these tombs.
Were there any other artifacts?
I'm looking for work.
I have recovered Jacob's blessed quill from the evil Gilles.
I have recovered the ancient Holy Symbol of Tyr.
I have recovered Halueth Never's rusted armor.
I have recovered the Ancient Chronicles of Never.
